text: Executive Summary Welcome everyone! Welcome to the 423rd episode of the Financial Advisor Success Podcast! My guest on today's podcast is Cristina Livadary. Cristina is the CEO of Mana Financial Life Design, an RIA based in Los Angeles, California (but works virtually with clients nationwide), that oversees approximately $70 million in assets under management for 119 client households. What's unique about Cristina, though, is how her firm supports clients in the so-called "sandwich generation" by both creating a financial plan for the clients' personal financial needs and goals, and by addressing (often with a separately paid add-on financial planning engagement) the financial issues facing their aging (and frequently less financially secure) parents who they may someday need to support. In this episode, we talk in-depth about how Cristina's personal experience dealing with challenging issues with her own aging parents while simultaneously caring for her young children helped her recognize the challenges those in the "sandwich generation" face, how Cristina leveraged the research she did for her personal situation (including finding appropriate care for her mother after she was diagnosed with dementia) to create blog and newsletter content that resonated with both prospects and her current clients, and how this focus evolved into Cristina now providing planning services for both her working-age clients as well as their parents (either as an add-on service to their child's engagement or, for those who can afford her firm's fees, as a separate client household). We also talk about how Cristina started Mana Financial Life Design from scratch after working as an investment wholesaler earlier in her career (teaming up with her best friend who brings complementary skills to the business), how Cristina used a convertible note to raise money from her friends and family to get her business off the ground (and how she was ultimately able to pay off the note with interest before it converted into equity), and how Cristina successfully transitioned from charging clients a $2,400 annual planning fee to a complexity-based fee (with a $10,000 annual minimum) by linking the fees she charges to the specific service needs of each client (and the amount of time it takes to do so). And be certain to listen to the end, where Cristina shares how she uses 20-minute "fit" meetings to determine whether prospective clients will be a good match for her firm's service offering and fee model (thereby minimizing the number of bad-fit clients her firm takes on), the key lessons Cristina learned from earlier hiring mistakes (particularly the importance of determining a defined role for each new hire in advance of putting out a job posting), and how Cristina leverages the artificial-intelligence-powered notetaking software tool Fathom AI not only to turn around meeting notes and follow-up tasks faster, but also so that she and her team can be more present during client meetings (without having the burden of simultaneously taking notes while trying to stay focused on what the client is saying). So, whether you're interested in learning about serving clients in the "sandwich generation" (and their parents), building a firm from scratch alongside a trusted business partner, or how to hold effective "fit" meetings to ensure a solid match with prospective clients, then we hope you enjoy this episode of the Financial Advisor Success podcast, with Cristina Livadary. Michael Kitces is Head of Planning Strategy at Focus Partners Wealth, which provides an evidence-based approach to private wealth management for near- and current retirees, and Focus Partners Advisor Solutions, a turnkey wealth management services provider supporting thousands of independent financial advisors through the scaling phase of growth. In addition, he is a co-founder of the XY Planning Network, AdvicePay, fpPathfinder, and New Planner Recruiting, the former Practitioner Editor of the Journal of Financial Planning, the host of the Financial Advisor Success podcast, and the publisher of the popular financial planning industry blog Nerd’s Eye View through his website Kitces.com, dedicated to advancing knowledge in financial planning. In 2010, Michael was recognized with one of the FPA’s “Heart of Financial Planning” awards for his dedication and work in advancing the profession. Read all of Michael’s articles here. Fill out this form to be considered! Full Transcript: Michael: Welcome, Cristina Livadary, to the "Financial Advisor Success" podcast. Cristina: Thank you for having me, Michael. Michael: I'm looking forward to today's discussion and what to me is an interesting dynamic of, as I understand, how your firm has evolved in clients that it works with intergenerationally. There's a thing in our industry these days of, I don't even know what the number is, a bajillion trillion dollars of wealth is going to transfer from an older generation of folks to the next generation, to their children, to their heirs. Therefore, if you're working with retirees, you should work really hard to build relationships with their kids so that someday when the money passes down the family tree, you can continue to work with the folks that inherit the dollars. It's just kind of out there as a strategy, as I would even dare say, a recommended practice for a lot of firms, particularly if you work with older clients. To me, there's always been a dynamic of it that's felt really strange and off to me that, okay, I get it conceptually, we're hoping to build relationships with the next generation, but if you're really good at working with older retirees and relating to them and the issues that they're dealing with, you really might not be the most relatable to what their kids or grandchildren are going through, depending on how old the parents are and how far down the family tree you're going. We deal with different stuff at different stages of life. There's some generational dynamics as well of how it shows up that makes the experience of your 20s or 30s today is not what it was 20 or 30 years ago. But if you work with folks that are at that middle stage right now, there's a whole other version of intergenerational dynamics, which is, "Yeah, the problem isn't parents pass away and we're following the money down to the kids." It's "No, I work with the kids and their parents have problems." For any of us that are in our 30s, 40s, early 50s, often you get to live some version of that proverbial sandwich generation experience firsthand. I know you have dealt with some of this both personally, directly, and in the practice. I think I'm just really interested and fascinated to talk about what it looks like when you're trying to help more members of the family, not because you're working with the parents and you're trying to follow the money down the family tree, but because you work with the kids and their parents have problems. Cristina: Yeah. So again, great way to put that, Michael. Before I worked as a financial planner, financial advisor, I was an investment wholesaler. I heard a derivation of that initial line that you stated, $20, $30 trillion will be passed down. I mean, 2 or 3 times a week, right? And I also, at that time, was in my late 20s and kind of had the same thought of, how does that work? And so through the evolution of our practice at Mana, this really came more naturally than it came as a marketing tactic or a marketing strategy. It was really...when we started Mana, we wanted to have and cultivate a life planning-centric business. And I'm proud to say that six and a half years in, that we have and we lead with life planning in our practice, which means that we are not afraid to have difficult conversations with our clients. And as a result, I would say that because we've opened up the doors in our hearts to have these emotional conversations about life and meaning and purpose, our clients, as they've grown older, have started opening up about their fears, about their concerns with their aging parents. And that's from the client side. That's really where this focus on the sandwich generation really comes from, is the ability and the willingness for us to have these conversations with our clients. Cristina's Personal Experience Becoming 'Sandwiched' [08:24] Michael: I'm struck that you said this, this evolution to focusing more into sandwich generation clients, what they're dealing with, it wasn't the founding mission when the firm started years ago. It came about organically. So can you share a little bit more of organically how this came about? How did you end up going further in a direction to say I think this is a thing we're going to really start doing more of and focusing in on more? Cristina: I think, Michael, back to what you were talking about earlier, where when we started our firm, we realized we weren't going to go attract a bunch of retirees with tens of millions of dollars. We didn't know anyone in that demographic. And so we started working with people that were, frankly, a lot like us. So we were in our 30s and we were starting families, we were getting married. A lot of our clients and our spouses were working in technology. They had stock compensation. And so we really geared our main marketing messages around that demographic. How to plan for maternity leave, how to budget for your wedding. And so a lot of our initial foray into getting clients was really attracting people just like us. And similarly, as we grew and evolved, so 6 and a half years after launching, our lives changed. And so earlier this year, I personally became sandwiched, where my... Michael: It doesn't sound good when you use it like a verb. Cristina: Right? I know. But I faced... It started in 2023, where my father got very ill and my mom stopped picking up the phone as much. They were up in Northern California and I'm down in Southern California. And so we started getting a little bit worried. And ultimately, my father got very, very sick and passed away in January of this year. Michael: Sorry. Cristina: And then within a week of that, my mother was diagnosed with dementia. Michael: So in retrospect, that's why she wasn't answering the phone. Like she wasn't... Dad was handling things and she was having challenges already? Cristina: Exactly. Yeah. There was a lot of signals that I missed because I personally was not ready to handle it. I was 2 months postpartum at the time. So I had a lot going on personally, emotionally. Michael: So you had a baby a year ago. Cristina: I had a baby a year ago. And so it was...yeah, it was, it was a time... I remember vividly last fall where things were too much. And so I knew there was something off with the communication with my parents. We used to talk at least once a week. And so some of those calls started dropping off, and I was like, "Hmm," but I did have my hands full with our practice, in addition to raising a three-year-old and a baby at that time. Michael: So what happens next? Cristina: So that January of this year was the month where everything hit the fan. So I lost my father, mother had a dementia diagnosis. My son, who was four months old at the time, was hospitalized with COVID. And so was on ventilators, couldn't breathe for...even talking about it right now just brings me back to a uncomfortable position. Michael: This is the newborn. So he's 4, 5 months old? Cristina: He was 4 months old. Yeah. And it was a lot, it was a lot to handle. And I was expected, because I was the financial planner among my siblings and half-siblings, I had to take the lead on all of it. And so that's really where... I say this now, again, with many months having passed, but I realized I had no idea what I was doing, Michael. I was responsible for being the co-trustee of my parents' trust. My parents, it turned out, had become hoarders in the time that I hadn't checked in on them. And there was, and continues to be a lot to clean out in the house, a restaurant needed to be sold. And my mother was incapable of taking care of herself. So I had to figure out a plan for care. And I had to do that all within a span of several weeks. And so this is where I realized, "I don't know what I'm doing." And I'm a financial planner. Michael: So at least you have the financial literacy and the context and the rest of it, and it's still horrifically overwhelming. Cristina: Absolutely. Turning Her Experience Navigating Issues Surrounding Aging Parents Into Content For Clients And Prospects [14:26] Michael: So what...so I guess I'm wondering now, how did this play out for you? And when does this start to show up in the business? Cristina: So I did not stop working because it turns out I process things slowly. I immediately went into therapy, but I also wanted to continue working because I had this feeling that there, there was something here. And again, like you just referenced, financial planning is so critical to a successful outcome in this situation, right? Financial life planning in particular. And so one of the ways that I processed, not only my grief, but my desire to learn how to actually do things correctly or do things in a way, right? There's no right way to go about this, but to go about this in the way that I needed to go about this, I had to do a tremendous amount of research, but I also wanted to begin creating space for these conversations within our practice. And the way that I do that is through writing. And so we at Mana have a bi-weekly blog that we publish along with a bi-weekly newsletter. And for the first half of this year, I spent that time writing on a number of different subjects in regards to the sandwich generation. So everything from what does assisted living look like in all its multiple iterations. I was recording social media videos on the same topics, all the way to how to talk to your aging parents about money, about aging, about estate planning. And really through this writing, our clients started reading it and saying, "Hey, I saw that you posted about this the other day. First, I'm sorry that you're going through this, but second, my mom started exhibiting some of these signs. What do you recommend I do to really address this right now?" And so as I started putting out these blog posts and our team at Mana started also internalizing this and opening up the space for conversations with our clients, we started realizing that a lot of our clients were in similar positions as I was. Michael: So I guess I'm just wondering the nature of this content you started creating, what was the style? What was the approach? Is this education style? Are you outright telling people you're going through this with your family now, right now as well? Cristina: Well, I would say at Mana, our approach is always leading with the heart. Every one of our blogs starts with a story, right? And we always start with why this matters. And in the context of the sandwich generation, why it mattered to me at that time. So I do... I've gone to a lot of therapy, I've worked on myself. And for me, part of my processing is sharing. And so I felt very comfortable being able to, and again, just here's why we're writing about this. And really, a passion of mine and why I continue doing the work that I do is because I also don't want any of the mistakes that I made needlessly repeated. Michael: Right. So then can you share a little bit more of the kinds of articles you were creating? What were you finding, learning, discovering, putting out there? You said some different types of assisted living facilities and talking aging parents. Cristina: The first one was the different kind of assisted living facilities. And that was certainly one where, because I was trying to figure out what's the difference between memory care and facilities that say they do memory care but don't have lockdown, right? And so it was a very nuanced, here are the different categories of care facilities. The other, we've written about who are the types of aging specialists you can employ to help you when you don't have the time or you don't have the capacity to dedicate all of this, all of your time, attention, and resources to this. And so we talked about the network that we've built through this year of working with those in the sandwich generation. A lot of the work that we do is about the conversations. And so writing it from different perspectives. So conversations to have with aging parents, conversations to have with your adult children. Because one thing that I don't think we've mentioned yet, Michael, is that as a result of the work that we've been doing with our sandwich generation clients, we have found that it's not only parents "in trouble," but it's parents who need planning themselves, and maybe have worked with a traditional financial advisor, aka, only does investments for them, and have no financial plan. And so we've been introduced to this generation through their children. And so we've also done life planning work with them and unearthed some of their reservations, some of their fears. And we want to continue to address those fears through our writing as well. Michael: And so I guess in the sort of the truest sense from this, intergenerational framing, you effectively are ending up moving up the family tree and getting brought in to do planning work with the parents. Cristina: Mm-hmm. Very much so. Cristina's Experience Starting Mana Financial Life Design From Scratch [21:27] Michael: So help us now with a little more context of, I guess, Mana, the advisory firm, in the first place, I don't know as existed 12 months ago, before you started down this journey, because then I want to understand how it's starting to change as you're doing more of this. But can you give us the overall context on the advisory firm? Cristina: Sure. So Mana, shorthand is Mana, full name is Mana Financial Life Design. And I run it with my best friend and business partner, Stephanie Bucko. And we launched in 2018 with zero assets under management, zero clients. So we both had come from disparate areas of financial services. And as I'd mentioned, I worked as an investment wholesaler, ahead of launching this. And we've talked about this before to the advisory community, but ahead of launching Mana, and neither one of us had actually done a financial plan before. I had done the CFP coursework and I did that sample plan that you have to do as part of... Michael: Yeah, I feel like for the capstone class. Cristina: Exactly. And that's as far as I went, Michael. So I had never actually done financial planning with clients until we launched our firm. And... Michael: And it sounds like Stephanie hadn't either? Cristina: Stephanie had not either. So Stephanie had worked right out of college at PWC during the great financial crisis, auditing hedge funds. She is definitely the math brain behind Mana. I'm giving her full credit for that. And then after PWC, she went to work for the world's largest hedge fund of funds. And so she was a risk officer, and really understanding the underlying risk within the hedge fund of fund portfolios that they managed at Mangrove. Michael: So how do you end up saying, "Hey, let's get the wholesaler and the hedge fund risk manager together and launch a financial planning?" Cristina: Good question. So Stephanie had finished her CFA and CPA, and had really kind of reached a point in her career where she wanted a shift. And so a year before that in 2017, she actually went to work for a bank and was an investment manager. So was running a portfolio of a model of securities for private wealth clients of a bank. And so that's where she kind of started realizing, "Hey, this is not too dissimilar to how we thought about building portfolios on the institutional side. This is interesting." And she found a great deal of satisfaction working with individual clients. And from my perspective, I had reached a point as a wholesaler, where I felt like there was a big difference. And you've talked about this before, and who can call themselves a financial advisor? And I worked with folks, frankly…I'd worked with 10,000 financial advisors covering Southern California and Hawaii. And I'd recommend maybe a handful of them to my parents. So it was at the point where I was like, "Okay, Cristina, it's time to stop complaining and start doing." And so in 2016, I went to Hana [Hawaii] and worked with George Kinder on the Registered Life Planner designation after I read his book, "The Seven Stages of Money Maturity," it changed my life. And there, through the life-planning process, with that group, I realized that I had to go take the CFP coursework. And I worked while also continuing to be a wholesaler. In 2018 was the culmination where I got a sabbatical for working a decade at my previous firm. And I took those two months to really pause and first surf in San Sebastian, Spain. But while in San Sebastian, Stephanie came, and we put together a business plan. And we raised friends and family money to launch our firm and keep us housed, I'd say, for the first year of our business. We had savings, but learning lesson, double whatever you think that you need to launch a business. So we did that. And we launched with an email to everyone in our network, saying, "We've launched a firm." And that's how we got started, Michael. And it was it was up from there. But it was slower going than I had thought it was going to be in the acquisition of clients. Michael: So I want to come back in a moment to the acquisition of clients, more about who you're going after. But I'm intrigued with raised friends and family money. So what did you do? How did that work? Are there friends and family who own some percentage of Mana because they were capital investors in the startup phase? Cristina: So what we did was we issued a convertible note. And that convertible note was going to convert into equity within 3 years. But thankfully, we did well enough to pay them off. And our friends and family didn't truly want to own any share of our business. They wanted to see us successful. So ultimately, we did the convertible note. We had...it was really, really good experience for us and how to, A, fundraise. Michael: What were the terms of the note? Cristina: We paid them an interest rate that was what private equity equivalent was paying at the time, which was great. I mean, much better than interest rates today. But yeah... Michael: So they're making double-digit interest rates for a high-risk startup loan. Cristina: Exactly. Yeah. And so we did that for 2-1/2 years. And then we paid them off fully. And then Stephanie and I became the owners of our business. Michael: Was this tens of thousands, hundreds of thousands? How much did you raise to get going? Cristina: It was about $150,000. Michael: Okay. Cristina: Yeah. Michael: And that was mostly to cover salaries for you and Stephanie? Cristina: That's right. Yeah. Michael: Sounds like, just we're not the most capital-intensive business. It's not like you need to buy real estate and factory equipment and such. And it was just you and Stephanie to start. So you weren't hiring staff out of the gate. Cristina: That's right. Yeah. Michael: Okay. And so raised $150 [thousand] of capital in a convertible note with a market rate of interest and personal savings. Cristina: That's right. Michael: And an email to everyone you knew and said we launched an advisory firm. So what was the original advisory firm? When you sent the announcement email, what did you tell everyone you were doing and launching and trying to serve and accomplish? Cristina: I mean, it was simple, and I'm sure full of bravado, Michael, but it was essentially, "You know either Stephanie and I from friendship or our professional careers. We are extremely passionate about what we're building. We are focusing on financial life planning." And I'm sure I talked a little bit about the difference between financial advice and financial life planning. And I think we just opened it up and said, "If you've ever thought, 'hey, do I need a financial advisor?' Reach out to us." And so I had always been, in my work as a wholesaler, I spent a lot of time, again, thousands of meetings, asking advisors how they brought clients on. And some of the best advisors that I met had a fit meeting. And so that's really the way that we position anytime if you're interested in working with us, schedule a 20-minute fit meeting. And the fit meeting's purpose is to really evaluate if we at Mana are a good fit for what you're looking for. And so really kind of releases the pressure of needing to close anything or us pitching anything, but it's really, we're really trying to evaluate if we're a good fit. Michael: So what was the, I guess, just missing business model fee structure out of the gate? Did you have minimums? Were you just working with anybody who's willing to pay you as a good client when you're getting started? Cristina: Anyone who could fog a mirror? No. It's... Michael: So say most of us as we launch. Cristina: So we did launch with XY [Planning Network]. And so XY, we use a lot of the thought leadership that you and Alan had cultivated through that group to design our first of many fee structures, as you know, that evolved quite a bit... Michael: Oh, yes. Cristina: ... In the first few years. We did so much, Michael, for so little. Michael: What was it originally? Because I always find this fun to look back and reflect, "Wow. Look at all..." Cristina: I think the first one was like $2,400, so yeah, $200 a month. That was the first one. Yeah. And then we... Michael: For comprehensive financial planning and life planning, you need eight meetings or something. Cristina: That's right. Exactly. So we had always decided to charge two fees. So one was comprehensive financial planning, and that's the process we call financial life design. And then the second piece is investment management. And so we started at 50 basis points. And then very quickly, I think in the first year, we went up to 75 basis points for the first million and then a graduated reduced fee from there. Refining Best-Fit Services For Clients [33:29] Michael: And then did the planning fee evolve as well? I'm assuming you're not $200 a month. Cristina: Oh, yes. Yes. It evolved. It evolved through, not only our realization, but that, wow, we're charging this much. We're working this hard. How many clients do we need to bring on to live the life that we want to live? But it was also, we did a lot of evaluation on who we wanted to bring on. So I completely understand anyone who will fog a mirror was like that's...we always joke, but that is what you kind of have to do in the very beginning. But I'd even say in that first year, we started realizing, "Oh, okay, we need to start being a lot more nuanced in how we're charging based on the need of the client." Michael: So was the issue, if the fees on clients are this low, we're just going to need so many, it's too many, or was it more of... Cristina: Absolutely. Michael: ... We're just doing a lot of work and I'm realizing that I probably should have charged a higher fee given all the stuff that I just did? Cristina: I think it was both of those. It was both of those. In the first, I'd say the first 3 years, we created abundant processes, that looking back, were absolutely unnecessary. Michael: How so? What processes that were unnecessary? Cristina: So we use eMoney. We have all of our clients connect their accounts to the eMoney so that they can have a portal to view everything, just like the old Mint.com or Personal Capital. And what we would do is we would export every... First, we'd go and categorize every single expense for a specific amount of time. And I think at that time, we were doing this, Michael, weekly for clients. We were becoming bookkeepers without understanding. And so we'd categorize for the clients. We'd export them into an Excel spreadsheet. We made the Excel spreadsheets very pretty. We created a dashboard that synthesized the data from that spreadsheet and tell them what areas they could work on, what areas had they improved upon. And we sent this report and we had...there was no Zapier at the time. We had created these custom reports for every single one of our clients and manually sent them out to each one of them. I think it was once a week and then it became twice a week. And then within the first... We took a team retreat after the first year and realized that we had spent about 70% of our time on this form of cashflow. Michael: Did the clients like it? At least? Cristina: No. Michael: Hopefully? Cristina: Did the clients like it? Yes. Did it improve behavior? No. Did it... Yeah, did it have the desired effect, the desired outcome? Absolutely not. And what we realized is that we were doing a lot of the work that you have to do as an individual to be mindful of your own spending. Right? So if you have someone doing all the things... Michael: Because you made it so easy for them... Cristina: That's right. So where it is today is we do spend…I've recorded videos. Stephanie and I both have this and we have a client website that shows people how to utilize the eMoney portal and how to actually reflect on their spending, best practices on how often to review it, how to have a money date with your spouse to discuss this, if this is an area of focus for you. And so, again, as we've evolved through the years, we've realized that if this is important to someone, they will do it. And so we will show you how to do it if it is important to you. Every one of our clients today still receives a mindful spending plan. So it's not a budget, but it's, here's roughly how much we've projected you will be spending now into the age of 90 or 95 growing by 2.6% a year. And so, if the numbers are vastly different every year, then it's really impossible to create any sort of financial plan. And so that's kind of the way that we frame it now. And we are we are...life satisfaction as a financial planning professional, way higher now than it was back in those days. Michael: Because now the approach is, if you're not willing to periodically go in, if you're not willing to maintain the connections, if you're not willing to glance at even the reports that eMoney makes by default, you're probably not bought in enough that it's worth spending more time anyways. Cristina: Exactly. Michael: I like how you framed it. If it's important to them, they will spend time to do it and then we can guide them and help them. But it starts with, because it was important enough for them that they were spending time in the first place. Otherwise, we're not going to try, we're not going to bother because they're not engaging anyways. Cristina: Yes. Raising Fees To Reflect The Value Mana Provides Its Clients [39:36] Michael: So what else changed? What else saw launched in year one that looks a bit different now? Cristina: What looks the most different is the people that we work with. Michael: So how did that change? Cristina: So we worked with a lot of our friends as a result of the email, right? Is that that's who...and to me, that's one of the most beautiful things that resulted. A lot of people see that Stephanie and I, who have been best friends since college, we get up every day and we love working with each other. It is a blast. And I think people see that and our friends are like, "We love that and we want that in our lives. We want that team to be our team." And so that's where it began, really was friends started reaching out as a result of the email and we started bringing them on. Michael: So did that come relatively quickly for you? I know some advisors like, "I told my friends and then they basically waited 3 years to see if I was really going to stick with it. And then they started showing up." Cristina: No, it came very quickly for us in that respect. The rate, the pace of onboarding, I'd say it...we launched in July, we took our first client in September and we were bringing on 2 to 3 a month throughout 2019. And then...yeah, I mean, we were looking back at some of the numbers as a reflection, end of the year reflection earlier this week, and 2020 and 2021, we were taking on a serious amount of clients, 3 to 4 a month. I was like, "No wonder I was so tired those days." Michael: And are you still mostly at $2,000 to $3,000 annual fees for clients at this point? Cristina: I would say... Yeah, I'd say 2019, absolutely. I think we started raising fees in about 2020 when we started working with our business coach who was absolutely baffled at the prices we were charging. Michael: Okay. Or if you want to find the engagement letter of the client, just to double check something, we have all of those engagement letters in Airtable. If you want to find the IPS [Investment Policy Statement] of a client, we also have that in Airtable. So it's a receptacle for documents, but also qualitative and quantitative descriptors of our clients. Michael: Okay. And then how are you using Fathom in practice? Cristina: Fathom is amazing. And shout out to Rebecca Connor for teaching us how to use that earlier this year. But we use it to record client conversations. And we tell them ahead of time that we are using an AI notetaker to capture notes so that we can be more present in the client meetings. Michael: I like that framing. Does anyone push back on it? Cristina: We have one client who has pushed back because she's a very private person. And that's okay. And we also say that's okay. But the rest of our clients, we have not had... Michael: One out of 119. Cristina: Yeah. And then what we also found, because we integrated Toggl time tracking earlier this year, just to see... We have gut feelings about a lot of things, but really putting the numbers behind how much time do we spend doing X, Y, and Z. And so one of our promises to our clients is you will get an in-depth email that summarizes our meetings and your respective action steps as a result of the meeting the day after our meeting. And that's a promise. And every one of our clients receives that after a meeting. And we found that we were spending a lot of time summarizing the meeting in email. Despite one of us... There's always two people in a meeting. And we have a notetaker. And so that notetaker was never present, but was just taking notes. And so now we have two people and the notetaker. And so it allows both members of the team that are in the meeting to be very present. And Fathom takes better notes than any of us. And we'll summarize that. We've given Fathom a template of how we want it summarized. And Fathom spits out the summary. And so all we have to do is really just review it for completeness and accuracy. Michael: Interesting. So you're not just using Fathom to capture the recording and an internal summary. You're essentially using Fathom's summary output as what goes into the email, the post email to clients with an edit review. Cristina: With our template, correct. Michael: With your template and with an editing review for completeness and accuracy. Because sometimes it gets a little off. Cristina: And so that cut down meeting summaries from 30 to 45 minutes apiece down to 10 to 15 minutes. Cristina's Advice For Her Younger Self And For Newer Advisors [1:31:13] Michael: So what else do you know now you wish you could go back and tell you 6 or 7 years ago when you were starting down this journey? Cristina: For me when we launched...we talked a little bit about this, but we spent a lot of time creating processes. "What happens if we do this? How do we do this?" And part of me, yes, that was beneficial in some ways, but again, looking back 6 years, none of those processes are still around. So I think for my advice to earlier me is put a limit on getting ready to get ready and just sell. Go bring on clients. Which is ironic because that's all I did, was...so I think when we were creating this business, my sales, my passion for sales, my vision for sales kind of took a back seat because I wanted to learn how to do the other things. But in reality, I think a lot of those early pains could have been solved by more revenue. Michael: When I do find there's a sort of this awkward reality early on in any business, it's especially challenging when we're sort of systems- and process-oriented people, that until you have a certain volume of clients and revenue, it doesn't really matter if you're efficient. You already have spare time because there aren't enough clients to fill your time yet. So you can be wildly inefficient with 10 clients, it just doesn't matter. Finish your inefficient process and then go get your 11th, 12th client. Cristina: That's right. Michael: It does way more to move the needle than being more efficient about the 10 clients so you can free up more time when you already had enough time. Then you get more clients. Cristina: Well said. Michael: Then you get more clients and changes and then something matters, but early on, if there's enough time to serve the clients and go do business development, more efficiency doesn't really matter at that point. So is there other advice just that you would give younger, newer advisors getting launched, getting started with their careers today? Cristina: First off, I think if you're even considering being an advisor, the answer is yes. Do it. What an incredible career this can be for people, and I especially...our friend and colleague, Meg Bartelt, talks about this quite a bit, but as a female, there is such a need for more female financial planners, financial advisors that are doing the real work. And so if that's you, then do it because you will be successful. And there is truly an incredibly vast blue ocean of folks that need real financial advice. What Success Means To Cristina [1:34:43] Michael: So as we wrap up, this is a podcast about success and just one of the themes that comes up is the word success means different things to different people, sometimes different things to us as we go through the stages of our lives. So you have this business that's in a wonderfully successful place, you're cresting a million dollars just 6 years in. So the business seems to be doing very well and successfully. How do you define success for yourself at this point? Cristina: I would say the word that first pops into my mind is spaciousness. And spaciousness in my day's spaciousness in my weeks, and spaciousness in my year. So I think about that spaciousness in my days being, do I have time to just check in with myself, do a quick meditation before I go into a meeting and not feel rushed every moment of every single minute of the day? And then weeks, do I have time to pick my kids up and make dinner for my kids every night, which is, for me, that is successful me right there. Other things, having the ability to plan and strategize. That, to me, is...it's a result of success is the ability to plan. And another thing that success means to me is having the trust of my clients to shepherd them through this wild ride of life. Michael: I love it. I love it, Cristina. Thank you so much for joining us on the "Financial Advisor Success" podcast. Cristina: It was a pleasure. Thank you, Michael. Michael: Thank you. Quality? Nerdy? Relevant? Executive Summary

Welcome everyone! Welcome to the 423rd episode of the Financial Advisor Success Podcast!

My guest on today's podcast is Cristina Livadary. Cristina is the CEO of Mana Financial Life Design, an RIA based in Los Angeles, California (but works virtually with clients nationwide), that oversees approximately $70 million in assets under management for 119 client households.

What's unique about Cristina, though, is how her firm supports clients in the so-called "sandwich generation" by both creating a financial plan for the clients' personal financial needs and goals, and by addressing (often with a separately paid add-on financial planning engagement) the financial issues facing their aging (and frequently less financially secure) parents who they may someday need to support.

In this episode, we talk in-depth about how Cristina's personal experience dealing with challenging issues with her own aging parents while simultaneously caring for her young children helped her recognize the challenges those in the "sandwich generation" face, how Cristina leveraged the research she did for her personal situation (including finding appropriate care for her mother after she was diagnosed with dementia) to create blog and newsletter content that resonated with both prospects and her current clients, and how this focus evolved into Cristina now providing planning services for both her working-age clients as well as their parents (either as an add-on service to their child's engagement or, for those who can afford her firm's fees, as a separate client household).

We also talk about how Cristina started Mana Financial Life Design from scratch after working as an investment wholesaler earlier in her career (teaming up with her best friend who brings complementary skills to the business), how Cristina used a convertible note to raise money from her friends and family to get her business off the ground (and how she was ultimately able to pay off the note with interest before it converted into equity), and how Cristina successfully transitioned from charging clients a $2,400 annual planning fee to a complexity-based fee (with a $10,000 annual minimum) by linking the fees she charges to the specific service needs of each client (and the amount of time it takes to do so).

And be certain to listen to the end, where Cristina shares how she uses 20-minute "fit" meetings to determine whether prospective clients will be a good match for her firm's service offering and fee model (thereby minimizing the number of bad-fit clients her firm takes on), the key lessons Cristina learned from earlier hiring mistakes (particularly the importance of determining a defined role for each new hire in advance of putting out a job posting), and how Cristina leverages the artificial-intelligence-powered notetaking software tool Fathom AI not only to turn around meeting notes and follow-up tasks faster, but also so that she and her team can be more present during client meetings (without having the burden of simultaneously taking notes while trying to stay focused on what the client is saying).

So, whether you're interested in learning about serving clients in the "sandwich generation" (and their parents), building a firm from scratch alongside a trusted business partner, or how to hold effective "fit" meetings to ensure a solid match with prospective clients, then we hope you enjoy this episode of the Financial Advisor Success podcast, with Cristina Livadary.

Michael Kitces is Head of Planning Strategy at Focus Partners Wealth, which provides an evidence-based approach to private wealth management for near- and current retirees, and Focus Partners Advisor Solutions, a turnkey wealth management services provider supporting thousands of independent financial advisors through the scaling phase of growth.

In addition, he is a co-founder of the XY Planning Network, AdvicePay, fpPathfinder, and New Planner Recruiting, the former Practitioner Editor of the Journal of Financial Planning, the host of the Financial Advisor Success podcast, and the publisher of the popular financial planning industry blog Nerd’s Eye View through his website Kitces.com, dedicated to advancing knowledge in financial planning. In 2010, Michael was recognized with one of the FPA’s “Heart of Financial Planning” awards for his dedication and work in advancing the profession.

Full Transcript:

Michael: Welcome, Cristina Livadary, to the "Financial Advisor Success" podcast.

Cristina: Thank you for having me, Michael.

Michael: I'm looking forward to today's discussion and what to me is an interesting dynamic of, as I understand, how your firm has evolved in clients that it works with intergenerationally. There's a thing in our industry these days of, I don't even know what the number is, a bajillion trillion dollars of wealth is going to transfer from an older generation of folks to the next generation, to their children, to their heirs. Therefore, if you're working with retirees, you should work really hard to build relationships with their kids so that someday when the money passes down the family tree, you can continue to work with the folks that inherit the dollars. It's just kind of out there as a strategy, as I would even dare say, a recommended practice for a lot of firms, particularly if you work with older clients.

To me, there's always been a dynamic of it that's felt really strange and off to me that, okay, I get it conceptually, we're hoping to build relationships with the next generation, but if you're really good at working with older retirees and relating to them and the issues that they're dealing with, you really might not be the most relatable to what their kids or grandchildren are going through, depending on how old the parents are and how far down the family tree you're going.

We deal with different stuff at different stages of life. There's some generational dynamics as well of how it shows up that makes the experience of your 20s or 30s today is not what it was 20 or 30 years ago. But if you work with folks that are at that middle stage right now, there's a whole other version of intergenerational dynamics, which is, "Yeah, the problem isn't parents pass away and we're following the money down to the kids." It's "No, I work with the kids and their parents have problems."

For any of us that are in our 30s, 40s, early 50s, often you get to live some version of that proverbial sandwich generation experience firsthand. I know you have dealt with some of this both personally, directly, and in the practice. I think I'm just really interested and fascinated to talk about what it looks like when you're trying to help more members of the family, not because you're working with the parents and you're trying to follow the money down the family tree, but because you work with the kids and their parents have problems.

Cristina: Yeah. So again, great way to put that, Michael. Before I worked as a financial planner, financial advisor, I was an investment wholesaler. I heard a derivation of that initial line that you stated, $20, $30 trillion will be passed down. I mean, 2 or 3 times a week, right? And I also, at that time, was in my late 20s and kind of had the same thought of, how does that work? And so through the evolution of our practice at Mana, this really came more naturally than it came as a marketing tactic or a marketing strategy. It was really...when we started Mana, we wanted to have and cultivate a life planning-centric business.

And I'm proud to say that six and a half years in, that we have and we lead with life planning in our practice, which means that we are not afraid to have difficult conversations with our clients. And as a result, I would say that because we've opened up the doors in our hearts to have these emotional conversations about life and meaning and purpose, our clients, as they've grown older, have started opening up about their fears, about their concerns with their aging parents. And that's from the client side. That's really where this focus on the sandwich generation really comes from, is the ability and the willingness for us to have these conversations with our clients.

Cristina's Personal Experience Becoming 'Sandwiched' [08:24]

Michael: I'm struck that you said this, this evolution to focusing more into sandwich generation clients, what they're dealing with, it wasn't the founding mission when the firm started years ago. It came about organically. So can you share a little bit more of organically how this came about? How did you end up going further in a direction to say I think this is a thing we're going to really start doing more of and focusing in on more?

Cristina: I think, Michael, back to what you were talking about earlier, where when we started our firm, we realized we weren't going to go attract a bunch of retirees with tens of millions of dollars. We didn't know anyone in that demographic. And so we started working with people that were, frankly, a lot like us. So we were in our 30s and we were starting families, we were getting married. A lot of our clients and our spouses were working in technology. They had stock compensation.

And so we really geared our main marketing messages around that demographic. How to plan for maternity leave, how to budget for your wedding. And so a lot of our initial foray into getting clients was really attracting people just like us. And similarly, as we grew and evolved, so 6 and a half years after launching, our lives changed. And so earlier this year, I personally became sandwiched, where my...

Michael: It doesn't sound good when you use it like a verb.

Cristina: Right? I know. But I faced... It started in 2023, where my father got very ill and my mom stopped picking up the phone as much. They were up in Northern California and I'm down in Southern California. And so we started getting a little bit worried. And ultimately, my father got very, very sick and passed away in January of this year.

Michael: Sorry.

Cristina: And then within a week of that, my mother was diagnosed with dementia.

Michael: So in retrospect, that's why she wasn't answering the phone. Like she wasn't... Dad was handling things and she was having challenges already?

Cristina: Exactly. Yeah. There was a lot of signals that I missed because I personally was not ready to handle it. I was 2 months postpartum at the time. So I had a lot going on personally, emotionally.

Michael: So you had a baby a year ago.

Cristina: I had a baby a year ago. And so it was...yeah, it was, it was a time... I remember vividly last fall where things were too much. And so I knew there was something off with the communication with my parents. We used to talk at least once a week. And so some of those calls started dropping off, and I was like, "Hmm," but I did have my hands full with our practice, in addition to raising a three-year-old and a baby at that time.

Michael: So what happens next?

Cristina: So that January of this year was the month where everything hit the fan. So I lost my father, mother had a dementia diagnosis. My son, who was four months old at the time, was hospitalized with COVID. And so was on ventilators, couldn't breathe for...even talking about it right now just brings me back to a uncomfortable position.

Michael: This is the newborn. So he's 4, 5 months old?

Cristina: He was 4 months old. Yeah. And it was a lot, it was a lot to handle. And I was expected, because I was the financial planner among my siblings and half-siblings, I had to take the lead on all of it. And so that's really where... I say this now, again, with many months having passed, but I realized I had no idea what I was doing, Michael. I was responsible for being the co-trustee of my parents' trust. My parents, it turned out, had become hoarders in the time that I hadn't checked in on them. And there was, and continues to be a lot to clean out in the house, a restaurant needed to be sold. And my mother was incapable of taking care of herself. So I had to figure out a plan for care. And I had to do that all within a span of several weeks. And so this is where I realized, "I don't know what I'm doing." And I'm a financial planner.

Michael: So at least you have the financial literacy and the context and the rest of it, and it's still horrifically overwhelming.

Cristina: Absolutely.

Turning Her Experience Navigating Issues Surrounding Aging Parents Into Content For Clients And Prospects [14:26]

Michael: So what...so I guess I'm wondering now, how did this play out for you? And when does this start to show up in the business?

Cristina: So I did not stop working because it turns out I process things slowly. I immediately went into therapy, but I also wanted to continue working because I had this feeling that there, there was something here. And again, like you just referenced, financial planning is so critical to a successful outcome in this situation, right? Financial life planning in particular. And so one of the ways that I processed, not only my grief, but my desire to learn how to actually do things correctly or do things in a way, right? There's no right way to go about this, but to go about this in the way that I needed to go about this, I had to do a tremendous amount of research, but I also wanted to begin creating space for these conversations within our practice. And the way that I do that is through writing.

And so we at Mana have a bi-weekly blog that we publish along with a bi-weekly newsletter. And for the first half of this year, I spent that time writing on a number of different subjects in regards to the sandwich generation. So everything from what does assisted living look like in all its multiple iterations. I was recording social media videos on the same topics, all the way to how to talk to your aging parents about money, about aging, about estate planning. And really through this writing, our clients started reading it and saying, "Hey, I saw that you posted about this the other day. First, I'm sorry that you're going through this, but second, my mom started exhibiting some of these signs. What do you recommend I do to really address this right now?" And so as I started putting out these blog posts and our team at Mana started also internalizing this and opening up the space for conversations with our clients, we started realizing that a lot of our clients were in similar positions as I was.

Michael: So I guess I'm just wondering the nature of this content you started creating, what was the style? What was the approach? Is this education style? Are you outright telling people you're going through this with your family now, right now as well?

Cristina: Well, I would say at Mana, our approach is always leading with the heart. Every one of our blogs starts with a story, right? And we always start with why this matters. And in the context of the sandwich generation, why it mattered to me at that time. So I do... I've gone to a lot of therapy, I've worked on myself. And for me, part of my processing is sharing. And so I felt very comfortable being able to, and again, just here's why we're writing about this. And really, a passion of mine and why I continue doing the work that I do is because I also don't want any of the mistakes that I made needlessly repeated.

Michael: Right. So then can you share a little bit more of the kinds of articles you were creating? What were you finding, learning, discovering, putting out there? You said some different types of assisted living facilities and talking aging parents.

Cristina: The first one was the different kind of assisted living facilities. And that was certainly one where, because I was trying to figure out what's the difference between memory care and facilities that say they do memory care but don't have lockdown, right? And so it was a very nuanced, here are the different categories of care facilities. The other, we've written about who are the types of aging specialists you can employ to help you when you don't have the time or you don't have the capacity to dedicate all of this, all of your time, attention, and resources to this.

And so we talked about the network that we've built through this year of working with those in the sandwich generation. A lot of the work that we do is about the conversations. And so writing it from different perspectives. So conversations to have with aging parents, conversations to have with your adult children. Because one thing that I don't think we've mentioned yet, Michael, is that as a result of the work that we've been doing with our sandwich generation clients, we have found that it's not only parents "in trouble," but it's parents who need planning themselves, and maybe have worked with a traditional financial advisor, aka, only does investments for them, and have no financial plan. And so we've been introduced to this generation through their children. And so we've also done life planning work with them and unearthed some of their reservations, some of their fears. And we want to continue to address those fears through our writing as well.

Michael: And so I guess in the sort of the truest sense from this, intergenerational framing, you effectively are ending up moving up the family tree and getting brought in to do planning work with the parents.

Cristina: Mm-hmm. Very much so.

Cristina's Experience Starting Mana Financial Life Design From Scratch [21:27]

Michael: So help us now with a little more context of, I guess, Mana, the advisory firm, in the first place, I don't know as existed 12 months ago, before you started down this journey, because then I want to understand how it's starting to change as you're doing more of this. But can you give us the overall context on the advisory firm?

Cristina: Sure. So Mana, shorthand is Mana, full name is Mana Financial Life Design. And I run it with my best friend and business partner, Stephanie Bucko. And we launched in 2018 with zero assets under management, zero clients. So we both had come from disparate areas of financial services. And as I'd mentioned, I worked as an investment wholesaler, ahead of launching this. And we've talked about this before to the advisory community, but ahead of launching Mana, and neither one of us had actually done a financial plan before. I had done the CFP coursework and I did that sample plan that you have to do as part of...

Michael: Yeah, I feel like for the capstone class.

Cristina: Exactly. And that's as far as I went, Michael. So I had never actually done financial planning with clients until we launched our firm. And...

Michael: And it sounds like Stephanie hadn't either?

Cristina: Stephanie had not either. So Stephanie had worked right out of college at PWC during the great financial crisis, auditing hedge funds. She is definitely the math brain behind Mana. I'm giving her full credit for that. And then after PWC, she went to work for the world's largest hedge fund of funds. And so she was a risk officer, and really understanding the underlying risk within the hedge fund of fund portfolios that they managed at Mangrove.

Michael: So how do you end up saying, "Hey, let's get the wholesaler and the hedge fund risk manager together and launch a financial planning?"

Cristina: Good question. So Stephanie had finished her CFA and CPA, and had really kind of reached a point in her career where she wanted a shift. And so a year before that in 2017, she actually went to work for a bank and was an investment manager. So was running a portfolio of a model of securities for private wealth clients of a bank. And so that's where she kind of started realizing, "Hey, this is not too dissimilar to how we thought about building portfolios on the institutional side. This is interesting." And she found a great deal of satisfaction working with individual clients.

And from my perspective, I had reached a point as a wholesaler, where I felt like there was a big difference. And you've talked about this before, and who can call themselves a financial advisor? And I worked with folks, frankly…I'd worked with 10,000 financial advisors covering Southern California and Hawaii. And I'd recommend maybe a handful of them to my parents. So it was at the point where I was like, "Okay, Cristina, it's time to stop complaining and start doing." And so in 2016, I went to Hana [Hawaii] and worked with George Kinder on the Registered Life Planner designation after I read his book, "The Seven Stages of Money Maturity," it changed my life. And there, through the life-planning process, with that group, I realized that I had to go take the CFP coursework. And I worked while also continuing to be a wholesaler.

In 2018 was the culmination where I got a sabbatical for working a decade at my previous firm. And I took those two months to really pause and first surf in San Sebastian, Spain. But while in San Sebastian, Stephanie came, and we put together a business plan. And we raised friends and family money to launch our firm and keep us housed, I'd say, for the first year of our business. We had savings, but learning lesson, double whatever you think that you need to launch a business. So we did that. And we launched with an email to everyone in our network, saying, "We've launched a firm." And that's how we got started, Michael. And it was it was up from there. But it was slower going than I had thought it was going to be in the acquisition of clients.

Michael: So I want to come back in a moment to the acquisition of clients, more about who you're going after. But I'm intrigued with raised friends and family money. So what did you do? How did that work? Are there friends and family who own some percentage of Mana because they were capital investors in the startup phase?

Cristina: So what we did was we issued a convertible note. And that convertible note was going to convert into equity within 3 years. But thankfully, we did well enough to pay them off. And our friends and family didn't truly want to own any share of our business. They wanted to see us successful. So ultimately, we did the convertible note. We had...it was really, really good experience for us and how to, A, fundraise.

Michael: What were the terms of the note?

Cristina: We paid them an interest rate that was what private equity equivalent was paying at the time, which was great. I mean, much better than interest rates today. But yeah...

Michael: So they're making double-digit interest rates for a high-risk startup loan.

Cristina: Exactly. Yeah. And so we did that for 2-1/2 years. And then we paid them off fully. And then Stephanie and I became the owners of our business.

Michael: Was this tens of thousands, hundreds of thousands? How much did you raise to get going?

Cristina: It was about $150,000.

Michael: Okay.

Cristina: Yeah.

Michael: And that was mostly to cover salaries for you and Stephanie?

Cristina: That's right. Yeah.

Michael: Sounds like, just we're not the most capital-intensive business. It's not like you need to buy real estate and factory equipment and such. And it was just you and Stephanie to start. So you weren't hiring staff out of the gate.

Cristina: That's right. Yeah.

Michael: Okay. And so raised $150 [thousand] of capital in a convertible note with a market rate of interest and personal savings.

Cristina: That's right.

Michael: And an email to everyone you knew and said we launched an advisory firm. So what was the original advisory firm? When you sent the announcement email, what did you tell everyone you were doing and launching and trying to serve and accomplish?

Cristina: I mean, it was simple, and I'm sure full of bravado, Michael, but it was essentially, "You know either Stephanie and I from friendship or our professional careers. We are extremely passionate about what we're building. We are focusing on financial life planning." And I'm sure I talked a little bit about the difference between financial advice and financial life planning. And I think we just opened it up and said, "If you've ever thought, 'hey, do I need a financial advisor?' Reach out to us." And so I had always been, in my work as a wholesaler, I spent a lot of time, again, thousands of meetings, asking advisors how they brought clients on.

And some of the best advisors that I met had a fit meeting. And so that's really the way that we position anytime if you're interested in working with us, schedule a 20-minute fit meeting. And the fit meeting's purpose is to really evaluate if we at Mana are a good fit for what you're looking for. And so really kind of releases the pressure of needing to close anything or us pitching anything, but it's really, we're really trying to evaluate if we're a good fit.

Michael: So what was the, I guess, just missing business model fee structure out of the gate? Did you have minimums? Were you just working with anybody who's willing to pay you as a good client when you're getting started?

Cristina: Anyone who could fog a mirror? No. It's...

Michael: So say most of us as we launch.

Cristina: So we did launch with XY [Planning Network]. And so XY, we use a lot of the thought leadership that you and Alan had cultivated through that group to design our first of many fee structures, as you know, that evolved quite a bit...

Michael: Oh, yes.

Cristina: ... In the first few years. We did so much, Michael, for so little.

Michael: What was it originally? Because I always find this fun to look back and reflect, "Wow. Look at all..."

Cristina: I think the first one was like $2,400, so yeah, $200 a month. That was the first one. Yeah. And then we...

Michael: For comprehensive financial planning and life planning, you need eight meetings or something.

Cristina: That's right. Exactly. So we had always decided to charge two fees. So one was comprehensive financial planning, and that's the process we call financial life design. And then the second piece is investment management. And so we started at 50 basis points. And then very quickly, I think in the first year, we went up to 75 basis points for the first million and then a graduated reduced fee from there.

Refining Best-Fit Services For Clients [33:29]

Michael: And then did the planning fee evolve as well? I'm assuming you're not $200 a month.

Cristina: Oh, yes. Yes. It evolved. It evolved through, not only our realization, but that, wow, we're charging this much. We're working this hard.
